Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Peripheral Nerve Injury After Varicose Vein Surgery Using Endovenous Laser Ablation

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not applicable as this was not a randomised trial.

Participants.evidence: 25 patients underwent EVLA of the great saphenous vein (GSV) with or without microphlebectomy.

Intervention.evidence: EVLA of the great saphenous vein (GSV) with or without microphlebectomy.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to quantitatively evaluate peripheral nerve injury (PNI) following varicose vein (VV) surgery using endovenous laser ablation (EVLA).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was PNI, defined as >40% elevation in current perception threshold (CPT) from preoperative data. CPT was measured at 6 points on each leg preoperatively and at 1 week, 1 month, and 6 months postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not applicable as this was not a randomised trial.

Number_Randomised.evidence: From 2021 to 2023, 25 patients underwent EVLA of the great saphenous vein (GSV) with or without microphlebectomy.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Significant CPT elevation was observed at the knee joint level (P = 0.01) and upper portion of the lower leg (P = 0.008) 1 week postoperatively.

Harms.evidence: No major complications such as severe endovenous heat-induced thrombosis or major bleeding were reported.
